description: [Status: stable] [Name: superfluous-else-raise] [Message: Unnecessary {branch} after raise statement] What it does Checks for else statements with a raise statement in the preceding if block. Why is this bad? The else statement is not needed as the raise statement will always break out of the current scope. Removing the else will reduce nesting and make the code more readable. Example def foo(bar, baz): if bar == "Specific Error": raise Exception(bar) else: raise Exception(baz) Use instead: def foo(bar, baz): if bar == "Specific Error": raise Exception(bar) raise Exception(baz)
